4: Online Etymology Dictionary ratchet v. 1852, from  ratchet ,  n. . Transferred sense attested by 1977. Related:  Ratcheted ;  ratcheting . n. 1650s,  rochet , from French  rochet  "bobbin, spindle," from Italian  rocchetto  "spool, ratchet," diminutive of  rocca  "distaff," possibly from a Germanic source (compare Old High German  rocko  "distaff," Old Norse  rokkr ), from Proto-Germanic  *rukka- , from PIE root  *ruk-  "fabric, spun yarn." Compare  rocket ,  n. 2. Current spelling in English dates from 1721, influenced by synonymous  ratch , which perhaps is borrowed from German  Rätsche  "ratchet."

4: Online Etymology Dictionary 词根李平武蒋争 reprobate adj. early 15c., "rejected as worthless," from Late Latin  reprobatus , past participle of  reprobare  "disapprove, reject, condemn," from Latin  re-  "opposite of, reversal of previous condition" (see  re- ) +  probare  "prove to be worthy" (see  probate ,  n. ). Earliest form of the word in English was a verb, meaning "to disapprove" (early 15c.). n. 1540s, "one rejected by God," from  reprobate ,  adj. . 4: Online Etymology Dictionary brute adj. early 15c., "of or belonging to animals," from Middle French  brut  "coarse, brutal, raw, crude," from Latin  brutus  "heavy, dull, stupid," an Oscan word, from PIE root  *gwere-  (2) "heavy" (see  grave ,  adj. ). Before reaching English the meaning expanded to "of the lower animals." Used of human beings from 1530s. n. 1610s, from  brute ,  adj. .

5: brute     /   bruːt     ;           NAmE     bruːt     /         noun     ,     adjective           brute   brutes               noun         1     (           sometimes humorous )           a man who treats people in an unkind, cruel way           残酷的人；暴君         ◆   His father was a drunken brute.   他父亲是个蛮横的醉鬼。       ◆   You've forgotten my birthday again, you brute!   你又忘了我的生日了，你这个没良心的！         2     a large strong animal           大野兽；牲畜           3     a thing which is awkward and unpleasant           突兀难看的东西；麻烦事                   adjective         [ only before noun       ]       1     involving physical strength only and not thought or intelligence           蛮干不动脑筋的         ◆     brute force/strength     暴力；蛮劲         2     basic and unpleasant           根本而令人不快的；赤裸裸的         ◆   the brute facts of inequality   赤裸裸的不平等事实             brute     /   bruːt     ;           NAmE     bruːt     /
